ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to talk and write about art, as well as how to better appreciate what it means to really see a piece of art, as opposed to just looking at it.
How to analyze a painting and write a detailed paper.

I learned a lot about the pieces in the Yale undergraduate art gallery and also about art history and how to first take in a piece and describe it at face value and then progress to interpreting and thinking deeper about aspects of the piece.
How to deeply analyze a work of art in person through close looking, description, and interpretation. How to write a long analysis of a single work of art.
Analyzing art, also a sense of aesthetic appreciation which I did not possess before

In this class, we spend over two hours analyzing two works in the YUAG's collection. We learn to extricate the different processes of art historical argumentation -- providing visual analysis first, and only then interpreting from the details observed. This class teaches you to think clearly and argue effectively by assuring that statements and interpretations you make are grounded and not prescriptive. You also learn to find the benefit in observing an object for prolonged periods of time to continuously find meaning.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think almost every aspect of this course was great. I think it could only be improved slightly by maybe meeting twice per week for shorter periods of time, since by the end of class we tended to get tired because we spent most of the time standing in the gallery.

Strengths: It's great to explore the YUAG and take advantage of having it on Yale's campus. Professor Suthor is very kind and makes everyone feel comfortable participating. 
Weaknesses: Class can feel long sometimes because we just look at 2 pieces.
All strengths. Professor Suthor is incredibly engaging and receptive, and the program was well thought out.
I wish there was more modern art in the syllabus, but that is just personal preference and not her area of speciality so is understandable

This course is so stimulating with wonderful yet doable readings for each class that enrich the approaches to works we deal with for a chosen week. The class discussions are wonderful, and each student brings their own background (academic and personal) to enhance readings of the artworks. It goes without saying, but to have a class fully taught at the YUAG is also an unparalleled opportunity one ought not to miss out during their Yale career. The only weakness of the course was that I wish we found a way to handle objects to not only engage the eyes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in art. This is by far one of my favorite classes I've taken at Yale so far.
Yes!! Everyone should take this class.
Yes! It is a great way to learn about the pieces in the YUAG and experience analyzing art.
Absolutely. This is a once in a lifetime to engage with an amazing university collection of art works on a weekly basis with an expert in the field.
